aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident in Watertown, Connecticut
The accident occurred in Watertown, Connecticut.
The accident number was ERA14CA430.
The accident occurred on September 9, 2014, at 08:25 Local time.
The aircraft registration was N20469.
The aircraft was a Cessna 172M.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The defining event was Controlled flight into terrain/object (CFIT).
The accident resulted in 1 minor injury.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The pilot was utilizing an iPad for navigation.
The pilot mistakenly landed in a field rather than his intended destination.
The intended destination was an airport with a turf runway.
After landing, the pilot taxied the airplane to a corner of the field.
The pilot commenced a takeoff roll from the field.
The pilot estimated the available takeoff distance to be about 600 feet.
Just after takeoff, the left wing of the Cessna 172M struck a tree.
The airplane subsequently impacted the ground.
The impact resulted in substantial damage to the left wing and engine firewall.
The pilot reported no mechanical malfunctions with the airplane.
The pilot reported no abnormalities with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of this accident.
The probable cause was the pilot's decision to takeoff from a field.
The takeoff from the field resulted in a collision with trees and the ground.
Contributing to the accident was the pilot's failure to correctly identify the destination airport and runway.
The pilot's failure to correctly identify the destination airport and runway resulted in an off-airport landing in the field.
Personnel issues included decision making/judgment by the pilot.
Personnel issues included identification/recognition by the pilot.
Personnel issues included flight planning/navigation by the pilot.
Environmental issues included trees that contributed to the outcome.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Watertown, Connecticut

## Accident Number:
ERA14CA430

## Date & Time: 
September 9, 2014, 08:25 Local

## Registration:
N20469

## Aircraft:
Cessna 172M

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Defining Event:
Controlled flight into terr/obj (CFIT)

## Injuries:
1 Minor

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Analysis

The pilot stated that he was utilizing an iPad for navigation, and mistakenly landed in a field rather than his intended destination, an airport with a turf runway. After landing, he taxied the airplane to a corner of the field and commenced a takeoff roll, estimating the available takeoff distance to be about 600 feet. Just after takeoff, the left wing struck a tree and the airplane subsequently impacted the ground, resulting in substantial damage to the left wing and engine firewall. The pilot reported no mechanical malfunctions or abnormalities with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:The pilot's decision to takeoff from a field which resulted in a collision with trees and the ground. Contributing to the accident was the pilot's failure to correctly identify the destination airport and runway, which resulted in an off-airport landing in the field.

## Findings

| | |
|-|-|
| Personnel issues | Decision making/judgment - Pilot |
| Personnel issues | Identification/recognition - Pilot |
| Personnel issues | Flight planning/navigation - Pilot |
| Environmental issues | Tree(s) - Contributed to outcome |

---
